entry.name: Aligned with global Z (vertical) axis (facing up/down)
Rotates around the vertical axis to face the camera, but does not tilt up/down
Locked to the camera, but can only rotate around one of the horizontal axes
Locked to the camera, but can only rotate around the vertical axis
Locked to the camera, but can only rotate around one of the horizontal axes

ActionID.name: Unknown
ActionID.description: ??? This is by far the most confusing action I've looked at. It controls the movement of the effect, but it does so in a very strange way, and I don't see how it could be all that useful, but I don't know exactly how it works yet. Action 129's field might have something to do with the strange behavior here, since it also affected action 34, which goes in the same slot as this. Still need to test this.

Field.wiki: Always 0
When set to 1, this seems to turn off the everything this action does. Not sure if it does anything else.
This only ranges from 0 to 0.1 in commoneffects. So, whatever this is, it must be pretty sensitive or something

ActionID.name: Spawner Rotation
ActionID.description: Controls the rotation of the particle spawner around its center Can be used with actions 401-404 since they change the shape of the spawner. Action 400 makes this not really do anything, since the spawner is a just single point in the center, so it just rotates around itself

ActionID.name: Position and Rotation
ActionID.description: Controls the position and rotation of the effect, useful if the dummy point isn't posiotioned correctly or you want to add a new particle on top that doesn't follow the dummy poly

ActionID.name: Random Position and Rotation?
ActionID.description: This haven't been tested at all yet, the notes are just speculation based on the values this action have in the vanilla FXRs This action probably does the same thing as 35, but with a range for each value that the game picks a random number from, e.g. you could set X position min value to 0 and max value to 1 and the game would pick a random number between 0 and 1 when creating a new instance of that effect.

ActionID.name: Play Sound
ActionID.description: Controls effect audio

ActionID.name: Random Particle Motion?
ActionID.description: Controls the random motion of particles in a 3d space

field.name: Particle Acceleration
field.wiki: Downwards acceleration. Can be negative values to accelerate up instead.

field.name: Max Angle of Random Turns
field.wiki: When the particles have acceleration from the property above, they will turn in random directions by a random amount that is limited to angles below this value. For example, when the acceleration property above is set to a negative value and this is set to 20, the particles will fly almost straight up, but some will fly slightly to one side. At 0, the particles move in perfectly straight lines up or down. At 90, the particles will pretty much move around completetly randomly, like a swarm of flies.

Controls how well the particles follow the effect if it's moving. At 0, the particles will not follow at all, they'll just stay where they spawned At 1, the particles will follow the effect perfectly, as if they are glued on Values between 0 and 1 makes the particles lag behind the effect a bit Action 34's rotation speed properties also affects the trail this can leave behind, so the whole trail of partciles will rotate around the center of the spawner

Field.wiki: Always 0
Ranges from 0 to 15 in commoneffects

ActionID.name: Spawner Duration
ActionID.description: How long the spawner will stay active for

field.wiki: How long this effect will spawn particles in seconds. If set to a negative value, it will never stop unless something else makes it stop.

Field.name: Spawner Delay
Field.wiki: Seconds between the effect being created and the spawner activating for the first time

ActionID.name: Particle Duration
ActionID.description: Controls how long the particles from this effect will last

field.wiki: How long the particles last in seconds. If set to a negative value, the particles will last forever.

Field.wiki: This has a strange effect on effects using action 105's 5th property (normally controls how well particles follow the effect) and action 34's rotation speed properties. When this is set to 1 while those other action properties are also used, it makes the particles fly away from where they spawned very quickly for some reason. Setting it to 0 disables this strange effect. Need to do some more testing with this to figure out what exactly is going on

ActionID.name: Effect Multiplier
ActionID.description: Controls a few things about how the particles from this effect looks and moves on top of the normal action that controls them, a good way to make deep colors is to add the same ones here

field.wiki: On one effect, this seemed to control the vertical speed of the particles it spawned, but on another it seemed to not do anything, so this is probably linked to some other property or field somewhere in some way

Field.name: Keep aspect ratio
Field.wiki: When set to 0, you can scale the particles in each direction individually using the scale multipliers in this action's properties When set to 1, the X scale multiplier will apply to the Y and Z axes as well, so the particles will maintain their aspect ratio. I think the two(?) other scale multipliers do nothing when this is set to 1.

ActionID.name: FXR Reference
ActionID.description: Refernces another FXR

ActionID.name: Disable Effect
ActionID.description: Disables the entire effect

ActionID.name: Spawner Control
ActionID.description: Controls how particles from this effect are spawned

field.name: Particle Spawn Interval
field.wiki: Delay in seconds between spawning groups of particles.

field.name: Particle Spawn Group Size
field.wiki: This is how many particels spawn at once

field.name: Total Number of Particles to Spawn
field.wiki: After the total has been met, it will never spawn more particles. If set to a negative value, it will never stop spawning unless something else makes it stop.

Field.name: Maximum concurrent particles
Field.wiki: If this limit is reached, no more particles will spawn until some have timed out.

ActionID.name: Single Spawn
ActionID.description: Controls how particles from this effect are spawned, makes them only spawn once, and never again

ActionID.name: Spawner(Single Point)
ActionID.description: Controls the shape of the spawner Makes the spawner a single point.

ActionID.name: Spawner(Circular, Ring)
ActionID.description: Controls the shape of the spawner Makes the spawner circular. Particles are spawned with their anchor points at random places inside a circle or in a ring.

field.name: Negative Dead Zone Fraction
field.wiki: At 0, there is no dead zone and the particles can spawn anywhere in the circle. As the value approaches -1, a dead zone appears in the middle of the circle where no particles can spawn, so they form a ring. At -1, the ring has no width and the particles will only spawn at the outer edge of the circle, exactly (Raduis) away from the center. Positive values will turn the shape into a single point, probably as a backup because the shape is invalid or something.

Field.wiki: This is probably some mode or something like that, but I have no idea what it does. When set to values other than 0-6, the shape turns into a single point.

ActionID.name: Spawner(Rectangle)
ActionID.description: Controls the shape of the spawner Makes the spawner rectangular. Particles are spawned with their anchor points at random places in the rectangle.

field.name: X Size
field.wiki: Distance between the center of the rectangle and the sides, i.e. half of the length of each side

field.name: Y Size
field.wiki: Distance between the center of the rectangle and the sides, i.e. half of the length of each side

field.name: Negative Dead Zone Fraction
field.wiki: At 0, there is no dead zone and the particles can spawn anywhere in the circle. As the value approaches -1, a dead zone appears in the middle of the circle where no particles can spawn, so they form a ring. At -1, the ring has no width and the particles will only spawn at the outer edge of the circle, exactly (radius) away from the center. Positive values will turn the shape into a single point, probably as a backup because the shape is invalid or something.

Field.wiki: This is probably some mode or something like that, but I have no idea what it does. When set to values other than 0-6, the shape turns into a single point.

ActionID.name: Spawner(Spherical)
ActionID.description: Controls the shape of the spawner Makes the spawner spherical. Particles are spawned with their anchor points at random places on or in the sphere.

Field.name: Spawn Inside
Field.wiki: When set to 0, particles are only spawned on the surface of the sphere. When set to 1, particles can spawn anywhere inside the sphere.

ActionID.name: Spawner(Cuboidal)
ActionID.description: Controls the shape of the spawner Makes the spawner cuboidal. Particles are spawned with their anchor points at random places on or in the cuboid.

field.name: X Size
field.wiki: Distance between the center of the cuboid and the faces, i.e. half of the length of each side

field.name: Y Size
field.wiki: Distance between the center of the cuboid and the faces, i.e. half of the length of each side

field.name: Z Size
field.wiki: Distance between the center of the cuboid and the faces, i.e. half of the length of each side

Field.wiki: When this is set to something >6, the shape just turns back into a single point. I couldn't see anything different when testing values 0-6, they all seemed to work the same way. In the FXRs I've looked at, this is always either 0 or 6, but I haven't checked very many. 401 also have a similar field, that could be worth looking into.
When set to 0, particles are only spawned on the surface of the cuboid. When set to 1, particles can spawn anywhere inside the cuboid.

ActionID.name: Random Rotation?
ActionID.description: Controls the random rotations of particles

field.name: Maximum Random Rotation
field.wiki: In degrees. Particles are given a random rotation when spawned, and this controls how far off their default rotation they can be.

ActionID.name: Static Texture
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look Similar to 603, but with far fewer options. Probably the simplest action to use if you just want an effect to spawn simple 2D particles.

field.name: Color*
field.wiki: The color is chosen when the particle spawns and it will stay that color until it expires.

field.name: Brightness*?
field.wiki: Probably brightness multipliers, just haven't tested them

field.name: Brightness*?
field.wiki: Probably brightness multipliers, just haven't tested them

Field.wiki: Always -2?
Always -2?
Always 0
Always 0
Always 1
Always 8
Always 0

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Minimum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

field.name: Maximum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.
Always 0
Always 0
Always 0
Always 0
Always 0
Always 0
Always 0

ActionID.name: Line
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look This creates simple 1px thick lines. Useful for sparks and things like that.

field.name: Start Color
field.wiki: End of the line color. One color fades to the other along the line.

field.name: End Color
field.wiki: Start of the line color. One color fades to the other along the line.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Minimum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

field.name: Maximum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

ActionID.name: Basic Rectangle
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look This creates simple colored rectangles

field.name: Top Color
field.wiki: This controls the upper square's color. One color fades to the other across the rectangle.

field.name: Bottom Color
field.wiki: This controls the lower square's color. One color fades to the other along the line.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Minimum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

field.name: Maximum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

ActionID.name: Animated Texture
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look

field.name: X Offset
field.wiki: X Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Y Offset
field.wiki: Y Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Z Offset
field.wiki: Z Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Color*
field.wiki: The color is chosen when the particle spawns and it will stay that color until it expires.

field.name: Opacity Threshold
field.wiki: The range is 0-255. Parts of the particle that have less opacity than this value will be invisible.

field.name: Negative Z Position?
field.wiki: Seems to work exactly like the Z position, but the axis is flipped around

Field.name: Horizontal Texture Frames
Field.wiki: How many frames are stacked horizontally in the texture sheet.

Field.name: Texture Frames
Field.wiki: How many frames are in the texture sheet in total.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Minimum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

field.name: Maximum View Distance
field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

ActionID.name: Texture Blend
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look Similar to 603, but this can have three different textures that blend together in some way

field.name: X Offset
field.wiki: X Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Y Offset
field.wiki: Y Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Z Offset
field.wiki: Z Offset from the anchor point, can be very useful for making particles move around. The other properties of the particle affects it, like the scale multiplier, particle rotation, and orientation mode.

field.name: Texture Animation Frame Index 1st
field.wiki: The index of the frame to show of the texture animation. The offset above is added onto this. If it exceeds the number of frames in the animation, it loops around to the beginning again. Can be animated using an A64 B16 property or similar

field.name: Texture X scroll speed 2nd
field.wiki: Positive = right

field.name: Texture Y scroll speed 2nd
field.wiki: Positive = up

field.name: Texture X scroll speed 3rd
field.wiki: Positive = right

field.name: Texture Y scroll speed 3rd
field.wiki: Positive = up

Field.name: Horizontal Texture Frames
Field.wiki: How many frames are stacked horizontally in the texture sheet.

Field.name: Texture Frames
Field.wiki: How many frames are in the texture sheet in total.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.name: Distance Fade: Far 1
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera increases.

field.wiki: When the distance between the camera and a particle from this effect is outside of this range, the particle will not be visible. Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

Can be set to negative values to make the particles visible from any distance. Setting just one of them to a negative value will only remove the restriction from that side of the range.

ActionID.name: Model
ActionID.description: Controls how the particles from this effect look This uses a model instead of just a flat plane with a texture on it

field.name: Color*
field.wiki: The color is chosen when the particle spawns and it will stay that color until it expires.

Field.name: Horizontal Texture Frames
Field.wiki: How many frames are stacked horizontally in the texture sheet.

ActionID.description: Normal trails (Not to be confused with weapon traces)

ActionID.name: Distortion Texture
ActionID.description: Textured square with distortion effect

Field.name: Background Blend Type?
Field.wiki: Affects how the particles are blended with the background in some way?

field.name: Distance Fade: Close 0
field.wiki: Controls something about how the particles fade away as the distance to the camera decreases.

ActionID.name: Light Source
ActionID.description: A simple point light

Field.name: Light Falloff
Field.wiki: This seems to affect the light falloff in some way, though I'm not really sure how. It does not affect the specular lighting.
When this is set to false, the specular color will be the same as the light color. Set to true to enable the specular color.

ActionID.name: Tracer
ActionID.description: Weapon traces (long 1 pixel wide traces across the weapon)

field.name: Segment Texture Width
field.wiki: How much of the width of the texture should be used per segment. 0: a single column of pixels is used for the entire trail. 0-1: a portion of the width is used for each segment. For example, setting this to 0.5 would make 2 segments show the full texture, and if there were more than 2 segments, the texture would be repeated. 1: the full width of the texture is used for each segment. >1: the texture is repeated on every segment.
